description.text:
We had to keep our cat from climbing up some stuff behind the door so we decided to just keep the door open. As the usual floor doorstopper was unhandy in this situation i quickly drew one in sketchup.
It was my first usable printed thing about a month ago and i unfortunately lost the sketchup file.

• print
  • mount wherever it's handy for you
  • keep the door opened ;-)

The last of my "knock 'em out fast and throw them on the table" wargaming troops. This time a pair of skirmishing figures (with a bit of paint thrown on them from a distance) -
1) a Spearman with light shield. Or replace the spear with a sling and you've got a slinger (obviously). He's a bit out of focus on the piccy.

Again I've put narrow gauge wire for their weapons as the plastic versions are too fragile for the wargames table.

comments.author: Frankn

comments.text: It is a scan ;) I did it with my DAVID SLS-1 structured light scanner. All my models - except the lion skull and the dog skull - were scanned with SLS-1. Lion and dog were scanned with my old scanner, a DAVID line laser scanner.
comments.author: Frankn

comments.text: How are the scans? I've used the rotational scanners like makerbot's over priced piece of junk and it takes terrible scans, especially if the object is reflective. Do you have to clean them up at all or is this a raw scan? It looks incredible compared to what I usually see.
comments.author: JulPal

comments.text: I do my scans with a structured light scanner called DAVID SLS-1. Each model consists of at least 15 scans which I assemble manually by using the David software. After assembling I export the model to another software to clean polygon spikes and other errors like non-manifold edges, tunnels, and holes.

description.text:
If you like to play with colors and light moods, this vase may be the right for you.
The vase comes in two parts where had to glued together. So it's easy to print in different colors or as single vase only.
The foot has space for a remote controlled battery supplied spot. If you decide to get rid of battery power, you can convert with a little hardware hack the lamp to wire supply by a 4,5 V socket supply. The foot is prepared with a cable slot for this case.
The lamps are in fact waterproof, but i decided to place it outside for easier handling. Who likes to fish them out of bad flower pot water? Also they will loose their water proof properties after the conversation to a cable supply.
Anyway, if the vase is transparent it will be no problem to control it by the shipped IR controller without lifting of the vase. In my case i was able to control some random functions of my HDD-Reciver too.

The project and the illumination with this handy lamps where inspired by nice user drato : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1691927

The lamps can be bought for example in the bookstore :
https://www.amazon.de/Soondar%C2%AE-Wasserdicht-Treffen-Weihnachtsgeschenke-Schwimmleuchte/dp/B017AUFLAQ/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1469616105&sr=8-2&keywords=soondar+led

or https://www.amazon.com/Soondar%C2%AE-Submersible-Waterproof-Wedding-Controller/dp/B00NUYM1ZA/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1469616131&sr=8-1&keywords=soondar+led

Detailed instructions to convert the LED Spots can be found here on my instructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Mood-Vase-1/step3/Fuel-change/

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,28

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I would recommend transparent and neutral PETG for the vase. Gluing the foot and vase works well with UHU PLUS ACRYLIT. (TM)
Due many trials and errors i figured out that is impossible (for me?) to print a real waterproof vase. After a few minutes they started to leak :( I solved this problem by coating it inside with simple wax. The PETG filament i used is heat resistant enough tho melt the wax carefully by a heat gun and let it soak between the perimeters. A detailed description can be found by an clever instructable that gave me the important hint:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Using-Wax-to-Waterproof-3D-Prints/

Designed with freeCad. The important part was to get an even thick wall of the vase. Otherwise the slicier will convert it in diffrent perimeter counts and infill's. At least this results in ugly looking spots in the transparent material.

Conversation of the Lamps

The simplest way of converting the lamps would be drilling a hole in the top part and lead two thin wires in. Then solder it on the battery contacts to the + / - clamps. The wall socket supply must have 4,5 volts.

title: Tiny epic western Board game storage

description.text:
Ever played the game Tiny Epic Western, and had a wish to ditch the plastic bags that come with it? Look no further. ( or do, I can't really force ya can I?)

This storage solution will simplify the storage of the tokens, dealer chip and cards, by introducing a box-design with lids to keep the tokens safely put away, two meeple racks to keep those little guys safe, a card rack to keep the cards from sliding around, and finally a little box for the dealer chip (more of a practicality than anything else as I didn't like it sliding around inside the box and for the aesthetic principle of having every token in a box. Seems a bit silly to just leave it lying in the box all by itself, sliding around and making a racket)

Also it offers a more long term storage life solution than those pesky grip lock plastic bags that comes with the game. (At least what I got, experiences may vary)

What you need:

1 token storage box + Lid
1 Card rack
2 Meeple racks
or
1 Twin meeple rack

Optional
1 dealer chip storage box + Lid
(If you think you can live with the dealer chip being loose in the box you don't need this one. Although if you can live without this one you wouldn't need a new and durable storage solution would you? Just sayin')

Specs for my printouts:

Printer: M3D
Software: M3D beta version 2016-05-06-v.14.2.6-WIN
Mat: PLA, Deep lemon
Quality: Medium
infill: Medium
Layer height: 0.15
speed: 35mm/s

No supports needed.

Grateful for feedback if you got it. ( or just say "hey", "hello" or give me some great financial advice)

Notes:

The usual,
I had bad backlash setting as always so the dealer chip circle might be a little big, though this means if you're in the same boat as me it should fit right in.

Some sanding might be required to get the lids to fit optimally, as all printers tend to lay down the filament in their own quirky way.

As to how the meeple rack works, As all meeples aren't created equal, some should be bigger than the others. I found that I could use this to our advantage as I made the small end of the rack (Where the square hole on the meeple rack is, check the STL schematic for this one if you didn't already) a little smaller.
This means we can use the two fattest of the bunch as "locks" to keep the meeples from sliding out of the rack. Simple, small and easy solution that makes print time much less than a lid design rack or stack, and also cuts down on the amount of files that you have to print.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low - Extreme

Infill:

Low - High

Notes:

Use a raft if you have to, wouldn't bother doing it as eat's a ton of time, filament and gives you a bad finish on the bottom of the piece.

RES and INFILL is your choice, shouldn't need to tell you that more infill and higher res gives you a better quality print.
SAAAAANDPAAAAPEER (or use diamond files, love me some diamond files)
Hate plastic bags, nuff' said.

Watch here: https://youtu.be/9MoxOQDCkgE

Today's #3DPrintmas model comes to you as Koromon. One of the baby level Digimon from the original Digimon Adventures show. Let me know if you like this and would like to see more Digimon!

I created this model in Fusion 360 by using the sculpting environment. I used a quadball for the main body and a box for the ears. After I had the main shape I wanted, I created sketches in the shape of the mouth and eyes. Then I extruded those out and intersected them with the body to get the desired details.

After I printed it out on my Robo3D (settings below) I handed it off to my wife who primed it with filler primer. Then she used an airbrush to paint the pink body, and a paintbrush with acrylic paints to paint on the details.

Notes:

The photos show a model printed with Hatchbox's 1.75 PLA wood composite filament. My FFCP has lost its blue printer bed cover so I used painter's tape. Temp was 220F for the nozzle although this may be a bit high as there were strings. Bed temp 90F but if you have a good print bed you could go as low as 70F.

It's likely that at a higher resolution and slower speed the dome would be much cleaner.
To clean up: if using wood-PLA a light sanding with 120 sandpaper smooths things out. This model takes acrylic paint well, can be carved after printing, or stained.

description.text: The sorry about the orientation, it needs to be corrected. Along with additional support that needs to be generated under the main Wings and Ailerons.

Here's one of my makerbot goals for 20XX, a space shuttle!  Based on lofting a 3-view, there is some loss of fidelity.  Thanks to @matthew_laberge for the red ABS which makes it look AWESOME.
There are many parts I'd like to improve, but I remember hearing that creations are never finished, they escape.

So this model takes advantage of "tall" prints on the makerbot. It's approx. 125mm in the stl which my machine prints very well. I created some shims that print beneath the wings in order support them. By coincidence, warping under the wings actually helps the wings print better. Printed in ABS using 10% fill. My wife produced the .gcode using skeinfox. The defaults printed a nice surface (after some tweaks).

description.text:
I wish I had coffee grinds filament for this one ...

Baratza Vario is such a nice coffee grinder but the portaholder design is ... less than ideal: makes a mess everywhere, can't hold the portafilter by itself and breaks easily.

I designed this portaholder with a funnel for my 58mm Breville portafilter, but the design is OpenSCAD parametric and can be adjusted for a tight fit for a variety of other portafilters.

Features:

  • the portafilter fits tightly, doesn't let coffee grinds fly all over the kitchen
  • you can leave the portafilter in the holder (one handed operation)
  • you slide out the portafilter and this makes the coffee come out evenly spread
  • it snaps tightly into the Baratza Vario notches

I debated whether I should add a tray at the bottom or not (because there will still be coffee or water drips) but in the end decided to save plastic and print time.

I've been devouring HBO's Westworld series. All through it, every time I saw an image of the Maze, I pondered...

As soon as Delores unearthed the toy in the final episode of the first series, I thought... YES!

So, here it is. I know another member has uploaded a 3D printed version, but this is laser-cut, and the files can be printed out and used as a template for making a maze with hand tools.
There are two layers in the files - one for the base, with the positions of the walls marked on it, and one for the walls themselves. The ECP file is colour-coded for the order of cutting to prevent parts dropping out of focus during the cut.

The easiest way to glue the pieces together is to apply PVA wood-glue to the lines of the base, then press the walls into place. Once it's lined up, place a small board over the whole piece and add a bit of weight until the glue is dried.

title: Land Rover Discovery 1 Trim/Door Card clip

description.text:
This is that little red clip that goes between your door card and pushes into the plastic sockets on the door, which tend to break off when you get the door card off. There's about 10 of these per door, and they break a lot. Particularly on cold days.

These hold the door cards for all four passenger doors and the rear door card into the door metalwork on Land Rover Discovery 1 200tdi and 300tdi (these both say tdi on the back) and I think also the TD5 (which does say TD5 on the back) and on the V8 models of Discovery 1.

3d printed ones in blue either side, original land rover red one in the middle for comparison.

description.text:
Who hasn't wanted to build their own jet engine? It turns out to be harder than it first looks ;-)

This attempt at an axial compressor requires a lego axle, and a motor to drive it. A lego power functions motor is sufficient to create a slight breeze from this. I've tried driving it with a power drill at 2600rpm. This created sufficient output pressure to inflate a balloon to the point that the rubber started to resist, IE hardly any pressure, much less than you can blow. Unfortunately 2600rpm creates enough internal friction to partly melt and fuse the components when they stop, so I don't recommend it.

So why am I publishing this? Well, it works a little bit. Maybe someone can suggest improvements. And I think it's still quite cool. The scad source is available on github, if anyone wants to have a go.

The compressor has 6 rotor and 6 stator elements, each of which attempts a 10% compression (way too optimistic!). The stator elements snap tightly into the case, the rotor elements rotate freely between them. A lego axle runs down the central axis. If you intend printing this, I've attached axlex.stl and axle_hole.stl as test components for testing the axle fit.

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed this in PLA filament.
Most components can be printed straight to the bed, but I recommend a raft for the case.

Preparation

The lego axle has to be able to rotate freely through the stators. I wrapped sandpaper round a thin screwdriver to free them up. After a test assembly I also found that tiny differences between the stators caused friction on the axle, so a rolled up tube of sandpaper was used to even them out.

The rotors have to be able to grip the axle, but slide along it when pushed.

Smooth off any rough or catching edges.

Assembly

Start by inserting stator11 (the smallest one). Make sure it is fully and evenly cliped in. Place the axle through this.

Now place rotor10 on the axle, and push it down to meet the stator. It should spin easily.

Insert the next stator using the axle to guide it. This makes it easier than the first stator.

Continue inserting rotors and stators alternately until complete.

comments.text: you need bigger blades, that like a computer fan, you need at least like...100mm intake fan,  with a high pitch so it will grab more air. then you need to reduce the inside diameter like a cone. so big fan up front and smaller ones in the back, like 50 to 70 mm.
comments.author: nicklindenmuth

comments.text: It has reducing fan sizes and increasing inner cone so that each stage reduces the cross section area by 10%, converging to a point 2/3 out from the center.
comments.author: nicklindenmuth

comments.text: If you can re-design for a 8mm axle and 608 bearings (22mm OD), you can probably spin it up as fast as your motor will drive it without melting problems.

comments.text: Yeah, I've seen some designs for centrifugal compressors using axles like that. I hoped this would be lego compatible. Some guestimate calculations say it would need to spin at ~120K rpm to be effective, but the blades would experience 400K g at that speed, which would probably make it explode unpleasantly.

print_settings.Notes:: (2)  The board is about 15mm thick by default.  Feel free to scale it to any thickness you like.  It won''t affect the puzzle.

description.text:
This is one of my favorite mechanical puzzles in the category of recreational topology. It is easy to make using wooden materials. For the curious minds, here is a 3D version. Once the two parts-- the board/stick and the bead-- are printed. Please use a piece of string (rope, yarn) to assemble it as illustrated. The challenge is to move the bead from the left to the right or vice versa. The main idea is to move the knot back and forth through the middle opening. Let's me not spoil the fun of the puzzle here.

Reference:

Gardner, Martin, 2008. Origami, Eleusis, and the Soma Cube. Cambridge University Press.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

(1) The board does not require a raft or support. The bead needs some raft for adhesion.

(2) The board is about 15mm thick by default. Feel free to scale it to any thickness you like. It won''t affect the puzzle.

Assemble as illustrated. You need a string that is about 8 inches or longer. Make a BIG knot of or glue the end of the string so they will not come out when being pulled. Plastic strings are actually easier to use.
Everything is done on 123D Design using some basic solids.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

print_settings.Notes:: If we were to work further with the pentominoes, we would want to make it more clear which side of the pentominoe needs to be face up. One solution that we had for this problem was to pause the print and switch colors about half-way through each print. This allows you to more easily see if your pieces are oriented correctly - the puzzle solution should be only one color, if you see both colors you know that those pieces are not correctly oriented.

description.text: The pentominoes created in these files represent different geometric figures that fit together like a puzzle to create thousands of different rectangular solutions. The challenge is presented as follows: Given 18 pentominoes, the task is to find a rectangular arrangement using every piece - this puzzle is very reminiscent of tetris.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Notes:

There are 18 pieces to this pentomino set. Six unique geometric shapes are found in the “single print” file and 6 shapes are found in the “double print” file. You will need to do 3 prints to get your 18 pentominoes: one of the single print and two of the double print. The 6 duplicates then need to be flipped so you have no two pieces that are exactly the same formation.

If we were to work further with the pentominoes, we would want to make it more clear which side of the pentominoe needs to be face up. One solution that we had for this problem was to pause the print and switch colors about half-way through each print. This allows you to more easily see if your pieces are oriented correctly - the puzzle solution should be only one color, if you see both colors you know that those pieces are not correctly oriented.

We got our original inspiration for the tower from John Rausch’s puzzles (http://www.johnrausch.com/PuzzlingWorld/figures.htm). We came across our biggest challenge with figuring out the sizing and spacing of the pentominoes to make sure that they fit together like a puzzle. Drawing them out on paper first, we started with each unit being 10mm, illustrated in the attached picture. We then ‘shaved off’ .25 mm on each side of every pentominoe. This creates a snug fit that still allows the user to move the pentominoes around with no problems. It was then a fairly simple process to create the files using Rhino.
JC, ML, CO 12/2016

We designed the pentominoes with the intent that they could be used in math classrooms. Students can explore the concept of different shapes having the same area by finding different solutions for the pentominoes. Students can also use the puzzle to practice their problem solving techniques or to create a little friendly competition in the class. If many people are finding solutions, you can keep track of which solutions are unique and which are duplicates. Despite the huge number of possible solutions the puzzle is incredibly difficult. Whatever your pentominoes are for, they are a great piece to show anyone how fun it is it bring math to life with a 3D printer.

I whipped up this wheel so that I could mount some 1.9 crawler tyres on the front of my RC hot rod for a dirt outing. This version has significant negative offset (rear bearing face is flush with the rear edge of the rim)

For assembly of one wheel you need:
(5) M2x12 mm screws
(5) M2 nuts
(2) 5x11x4 bearings/bushings (common in tamiya buggies)

You may want to scale the ring slightly, either to make it larger diameter, or wider, but since this is a freewheel I haven't had any issues yet.

Please note the CC-Attribution license, you are welcome to sell prints of this design, you only need to credit me (either link to this page, my webpage http://www.ossum.co.za or my facebook page https://www.facebook.com/ossumdesigns )

description.text:
Coming soon: An arduino Uno + proto shield version !!

EDIT 2018/03/04
Added V2 board and schematics with optional DC-DC 5V converter for a much better stability

EDIT 2018/03/01
Added more picture
Added new video
Added power-bank add-on
Released Levitator firmware 1.1
Released LevitatorHost 1.5

EDIT 2018/02/21:
Improved Arm and Coil Cylinder fixation.
Updated base for USB mini connection.
Added an Assembly and User's manual

EDIT 2016/12/15:
Added link to the LevitatorHost project

EDIT 2016/12/19
Added some PDF files for the board creation.

EDIT 2016/12/14:
Added more pictures
Added board schematics and gerber file.
Added Arduino Levitator project link.
Added Some build instructions
Added Levitator-Bottom-NoBTswitch part

This is my remix version of the great Gravitator.
My father was a scientist in the magnetic field and I've always been fascinated by his work.
When I saw the Gravitator, I decided to dive into magnetic levitation and build a unique Christmas present for him.

Looking on the web at some similar projects using an arduino to control the levitation, I came up with an interrupt based PID controller that can be configured and controlled over USB or bluetooth.

I've also developped the host controller that allows to fine tune the levitation.

As I wanted the levitating magnet to go up and down in a controlled way, I've also implemented a simple sine wave generator that interpolate between 2 predefined position.

Here are some small videos showing the
Beating Heart
controlled levitation

You'll find the arduino project here: Levitator
You'll find the Levitator Host application here: LevitatorHost

Some add-ons you might like:
Fiying Biplane
Flying Biplane - smaller
Flying Xmas Tree
Flying Heart
12.6V Power-Bank

Let me kown when you build one and post pictures !!!

Enjoy ;-)

Magnetic Fields and PID Control loop

This project let's you explore the magic of magnetic field with a fun and ready to use arduino projet.

  • A few printed parts.
  • Some simple electronic components.
  • An Arduino Nano.

and you're all set for some magic.

You're looking for a fun presentation of magnetif field generation ?
This project is for you.

You're looking for a practical implementation of a PID control loop ?
This project is for you.

You're looking for an "advance" Arduino programming project ?
This project is for you.

You just want to show your beloved one, how your heart if flying and pulsing when you think at her/him ?
This project is for you :-)

Print

Print all the parts as explained in the Assembly And User's Manual.

Build the control board

Get all the electronic components and build the control board as explained in the Assembly And User's Manual.

Assembly

Follow the assembly procedure as explained in the Assembly And User's Manual

Program the Arduino Nano

Download the Arduino project and flash the Arduino Nano as explained in the Assembly And User's Manual

Launch the LevitatorHost application

Download and launch the LevitatorHost application as explained int the Assembly And User's Manual

Have fun Levitating objects

You can now start experimenting levitation as explained in the Assembly And User's Manual

Share your experience

If you build this project please share pictures and comments

Have Fun

Printed parts

I've printed all parts at 0.25mm, 25% infill.

  • 1 x Base-Bottom : support doesn't matter
    or

  • 1 x Base-Bottom-NoBTswitch: (if you don't want bluetooth or don't intend to turn it off)

  • 1 x Base-Top : support >45° overhang
  • 1 x Side : no support !!! (otherwise you'll have difficulties to clean up the conduits.
  • 1 x Sensor Holder : support >60° overhang (so you don't have to clean the thread path)
  • 1 x Sensor Cap : support >60° overhang (so you don't have to clean the thread path)
  • 1 x Cylinder Body : support >45° overhang
  • 1 x Cylinder Top : support doesn't matter
  • 1 x Cylinder Cap : support >60°
  • 1 x Coil A : support doesn't matter
  • 1 x Coil B :support doesn't matter

Note:
If you plan to add the bluetooth module, consider using a switch to turn it off. Otherwise, you won't be able to flash the arduino nano via USB without opening the base and unpluging the bluetooth module.
Both USB and BT modules are wired to the same RX/TX pins and the BT will interfere with the arduino bootloader when flashing the board.

Hardware
  • 1 x Hexagon socket head cap screw M6x40 mm
  • 1 x M6 nut
  • 5 x Self tapping screw 2.9x13mm
  • 2-4 x M2.5x5mm screw (to fix the board in the Levitator base)
Electronic parts

For the Board

  • 1 x 12V 800mA power supply.
  • 1 x Arduino nano nano board
  • 2 x 15 pin female single row straight header (2.54mm pitch)
  • 1 x DC power jack 5.5-2.1mm, 8mm Diameter: power jack
  • 2 x 3mm LED, the color of your choice.
  • 2 x 330ohms 1/4W resistance.
  • 1 x 470uF polarized capacitor
  • 1 x 10-100nF capacitor
  • 1 x IRL540 mosfet transistor or equivalent (need to be TTL "compatible").
  • 1 x 1N4148 diode or equivalent
  • 3 x 2 pin JST male header 2mm pitch
  • 3 x 2 pin JST female header 2mm pitch + crimps
  • 2 x 2 pin JST male header 2.54mm pitch
  • 2 x s pin JST female header 2.54mm pitch
  • 1 x 3 pin JST male header 2.54mm pitch
  • 1 x 3 pin JST female header 2.54mmpitch + crimps

For the Coil/Sensor:

  • 1 x SS495A Radiometric linear hall effect sensor (or equivalent)
  • ~140m CU wire Ø 0.28mm
  • 5 x ~40cm 24-26 AWG wires to connect the coil and sensor to the board.

For the Levitating object:
Some very strong neodyme permanent magnet (N30 N42 N50)
You'll need one or more for the levitating object and you need one or more to put on top of the coil

To Add bluetooth capability:

  • 1 x HC06 or compatible bluetooth module HC06 module
  • 1 x 4 pin female single row straight header (2.54mm pitch)
  • 1 x Mini slide switch SS12F15G

Note:

  • Be careful, not all chinese Arduino Nano clone are born equals !!! Some are very poorly manufactured and thus very sensitive to noise or interferences.
  • A Nano board is extremly sensitive to shorts!! Be carreful when working with a bread board and wire al around. I've burn a couple :-(
  • The whole system is quite sensitive to the stability of the power source. I've tried several power supply and I still get some 50Hz oscillations that can destabilize the system.
Assembly And User's Manual

Please refer to the Assembly And User's Manual

author: Internauterne_3DLab

description.text:
This printer is designed to be as cheap as possible under 120 dollars. It was tested on design models and those went out well, but I am not sure about dimensions, because the screw rods are wubbling too much.

PLEASE POST MAKES

Ramps box is customized: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28210

Printer:

3D Creality

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10-20%

What you need

About 1kg of fillament (about 800g)
1 meter M8 screw rod
few meters of 8mm smooth rods (in this case i didn't used hardened ones only the ones from hardware store - 1 dollar per meter)
about 10 M8 nuts
20 M3 nuts
few M3 screws
About 50 M6x10 and M6x20
Arduino Mega 2560 with ramps 1.4 and drivers (look on ebay) http://www.ebay.com/itm/301754696422?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
j-head (not that makerbot small one) http://www.ebay.com/itm/282081935587?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&var=581032108842&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
3xmakerbot endstops
150W 12v power suply
aluminium right hand extruder (ebay http://www.ebay.com/itm/272363863219?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&var=571262076775&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)
30-50cm PTFE 2x4 (1,75 mm fillament)
NEMA 17 0,3/0.5Nm motors (0,5Nm for extruder and optionaly could be for X and Y axis)
2 30x30 fans
mirror/glass/laminat/... (what you consider as best build platform)
2 cable grommets http://www.hellopro.co.uk/Mencom-2710-noprofil-1000840-11742-0-1-1-fr-societe.html
3 springs (bed leveling)
Aluminum plate 3mm thick
Pneumatic connector for 4mm tube
(2-4 lm8uu bearings) in case of wubbling.-optional

Finishing printed parts

Everywhere where is supposed to be a screw and there's not hole for nut you need to heat up that plastic part or screw using firestarter or boiling water, then screw the screw into.
You need to aply similar thing with passive bearings (lozisko) mostly at extruder. You just print lozisko vozik extruder and boil the water, then take 8mm rod, put bearing in water and wait about 30 seconds. Then try to slowly push rod into bearing while twisting the rod, twist it until the bearing cool down.
If you have problems with these bearing you can replace them with lm8uu (recommended on Z axis on the side without motor)

comments.text: I have 150x120 and it was enough. For bearings is needed PLA and rest can be from both (I printed everything in PLA)

description.text: The tower of Hanoi created in these files consists of a rectangular base with 3 identical cylinder posts that hold 5 discs. Given a stack of n disks arranged with the largest on the bottom of a post and the smallest on the top, the challenge is to find the minimum number of moves to move the stack from one post to another. Moves are only allowed when a smaller disk is placed on top of a larger disk.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Notes:

The tower printed with minimal issues. We slowed the printer speed down a good deal when printing the actual posts to prevent warping/melting. We kept the printer bed slightly hotter than usual and made sure to spray the bed with a good layer of hairspray to help with sticking. The discs need to have a sticky bed to prevent them popping off the bed before the print is complete.

The initial files are in INCHES and the models in the photos were scaled down to 50% of the original size.

We got our original inspiration for the tower from RcNerdHW’s model of the Tower of Hanoi on Thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:511557). Using Rhino, we have very few problems creating the base. The biggest challenge came with determining what size the holes on each disc needed to be in order to easily move on and off the posts. We came to a conclusion that with posts of 0.5 inches the discs needed to have a hole of 0.7 inches to get the fit that we wanted. There is one file for the base and one for the discs. We printed 5 different sets of discs, each in a different color, so that the tower was more visually appealing. All of our prints were scaled to 50% of the original size.
You don't want to miss out on the opportunity to watch CO solve the Tower in RECORD time! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nm0ljMLemKs JC, ML, CO 12/2016

The tower of hanoi has several applications in the classroom, which contributed to our decision to create this puzzle. The first is having students derive an equation for the minimum of moves it takes to move n discs successfully from one post to another (2n-1). Students can also use the tower of hanoi to practice their problem solving skills or to simply take a brain break. Finally, the tower can be used to introduce the world of combinatoric puzzles. Whatever your tower is for, it is a great piece to show anyone how fun it is it bring math to life with a 3D printer.

description.text:
A perfect gift for a thrifty mathematician.
(Make sure that he/she is not one of those topology haters)

This is a piggy bank (coin bank) in shape of Klein bottle.
You put money in a hole and it travels trough a tunnel into a belly of Klein bottle.

I think it looks really good when printed with transparent/ semi-transparent material and with one perimeter thick wall.
When printing in this way, please check G-code in g-code viewer to make sure that wall is only one perimeter thick.

Numbers in the name indicates wall thickness: "Klein_bottle_piggybank_01" means wall thickness of 0.1mm and "Klein_bottle_piggybank_15" means wall thickness of 1.5mm.

For better looking prints, you can also lower layer height towards the top of the Klein bottle.

If you have any questions or wishes for different wall thicknesses or maybe just bottom thickness, please make a comment, I will see what I can do.

Printer:

Renkforce RF1000

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

It can be printed without supports, but it also depends on your printer settings.

comments.text: hi, i'm trying to print this but the model looks all broken in the slicer, and i don't know what to do. did you have similar problems?
comments.author: LoricGarde

comments.text:
you have to try different ones with different wall thicknesses and see which one will give good results. It also depends on extrusion width.
For example Slicer Prusa edition 1.36.2 : Nozzle size=0.4mm, External perimeters extrusion width =0.5mm, Detect thin walls=ON, Layer height=0.2mm, Klein_bottle_piggybank_04 makes a perfect one wall thick print.
comments.author: LoricGarde

comments.text: To extract coins, do you have to send them through the tube backwards again? That seems frustrating.
comments.author: hopewithus

comments.text:
Yes. If you look at the first picture: Spinning it counter-clockwise sends coins inside. Spinning it clockwise sends coins back outside. It is not that frustrating. Even if it is completely full, you turn it around couple of times and it is empty (depends on coin size - they come out in batches).
I wouldn't use exactly as a coin wallet, to pay with it in stores, but more like a saving bank, where you put inside spare change and empty it when it is full or you need money.
It is not the most useful compared to other piggy banks, but is very useful compared to other Klein bottles.
comments.author: hopewithus

title: Eros with the Helmet of Mars

description.text:
Eros with the Helmet of Mars, 3rd century. A.D., marble, Ny Carlsberg Glytotek (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now Remake) from Autodesk.

In Greek mythology, Eros was the Greek god of love. His Roman counterpart was Cupid (“desire”). Some myths make him a primordial god, while in other myths, he is the son of Aphrodite. He was one of the winged love gods, Erotes.

For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

Added a "Easy Print" version per request. It lacks the bottom wings but can be printed lying down, removing the need for supports during print. It should stick better to the print bed as well. Please be aware that I have not tested the "easy print" model.

Centripro is a simple GoPro mount for producing a bullet time effect on a budget, first invented by Swiss freeskier and film maker Nicolas Vuignier.

This is my version for the GoPro Hero 5 Black.
I've rotated the placement for the GoPro 180 degrees, the Centripro should now be swung anti-clockwise, this makes both the power and mode button easier to access.

title: Lego Leaf Wreath, No supports, widened, and optional Hanger

description.text:
I love to print without supports and made it so this would not need them. I also widened the openings to allow a proper fit without any strain or falling apart.
****EDIT: I just included another one with a hanger piece so you can hang it up on the door/wall and have it hang evenly without using the nobs. (this would mean for 8 piece design (octogon) so this piece witht he hanger can take center stage.)

I made this without realizing someone else also did it. So whoops, but funny how we both had the same thing in mind after printing this design.

I will also be posting item decorations we make for this. We are putting cylinder attachments to the back of items chosen by the family to represent our door. Neat idea, and we think it is neat to use this to put your own traditions on each year that fit the pegs.

Over the years, we expect this to get pretty eclectic!

***Added Sewing machine attachment. I made a remix of it from thing:858497 and made it so no supports would be needed and it would fit one of the notches in the wreath.

comments.text: Well it definitely works.  added the sewing machine to represent the wifey, will be adding more and am making a santa hat rightt now to just add random items to the wreath.

I have two bins with 8 Filament spools plus the two the mount behind the Printer. I mostly print in ABS, but will start to use PLA. So the first row will be ABS and the Second row with be PLA.

title: PSU low profile fan adapter (60mm to 120mm)

description.text:
Mind you: you are probably better of buying a decent new PSU, but if you're as stubborn as I am, read on....

I wanted to replace the noisy fan in my CTC PSU but didn't find a quiet 60mm 24V fan in a decent price range and with the same dB (sound) levels as normal for the quiet 120mm PC fans. Since I already had the 120mm fan I decided to make this adapter to place the fan on the outside over the fan vent after removing the original PSU fan. You need to have your 3D printer on high feet as I have (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1957836) in order to have enough space. I used a step down controller attached to 24V PSU to get 12V for the standard 120mm silent PC fan.
Even though the low profile of the adapter can reduce the fan's capacity the temperature I measured inside the PSU was very good, even a couple degrees lower than measured with the original 60mm fan.

Printer:

CTC Bizer Dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Since I used silent PC fans which are 12V DC, I used a LM2596S step down controller connected to 24V DC at the PSU set it to 12V and put it in an enclosure (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1306586). I cut some connector cable from an old PC PSU which has the same type of connector as on the fans.

print_settings.Notes:: These files can not be printed on a standard size Printrbot bed, you must have a volume upgrade.  The support legs and ATX mount could be modified to fit a normal size bed, but the LCD panel can't be given the size of the board it has to house.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Add-on System (Lower supports, LCD Housing, ATX Mount)

description.text:
I love my Printrbot Simple Metal and have upgraded it quite heavily, as do most people who own one. However, I couldn't find a system I liked to keep all the add-ons and cabling in place neatly, so I decided to create my own system. Space is an issue in my shop, so keeping everything in one tight package is important and also makes the machine much more pleasant to operate and look at. This add-on system is modular and would be great for anyone who has upgraded to a larger bed, a heated bed, and/or an LCD screen. This system does the following;

Raises the printer on legs to help stability and give extra room for cabling (such as the extended ATX power supply jacks)

Provides an interlocking, flush mounted LCD housing for standard RepRapDiscount 20x4 LCD display screens

Provides an interlocking ATX power supply mount

When printed and installed, the total footprint of the printer is utilized efficiently and operated sideways to provide easier access to the SD card slot. I connected the lower support brackets by sliding a strip of 1/4" sintra plastic through the central gaps, but it would be easy to make a printed part to replace this if that's requested.

20%

title: Belt driven Z-Axis / Worm Gear Mount

description.text:
This the Worm Gear Mount that I use for the Z-Axis on my TEVO Tarantula.

The worm gear prevents that the x-axis beam falls on the print (or heatbed) after the motors are switched off or if a power failure occurs.

I have prepared a short version that simply sits on a 2020 beam and versions with longer "legs" that can be used to connect a 2020 beam with a 2040 beam. If you do not want to loose any build height on the Tarantula you should choose the one with one short side.

All parts can be printed without supports!

Use flat washers for the screws that connect the worm gear mount to the 2020 beam. Do not overtighten the screws or the mount will break.

Watch this thing to get updates! Post your "I Made Ones"! Comment! Remix! Fix things I messed up! ;)

The worm gear´s transmission ratio is 1:20 an the pulley has 20 teeth. Therefore the transmission ratio is the same as in the original setup and you do not need to make any changes to the Tarantula´s firmware!

A part list / bill of materials (BOM) is available here:
English: http://blog.digidigital.de/?p=244&lang=en_US
German: http://blog.digidigital.de/?p=244&lang=de_DE

FreeCAD sources included. Some parts are sketch based. If you have to adjust hole diameters simply change the values in the sketches.

The X-Axis Connector is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1746434
I made it a bit shorter and have added a groove to allow the belt to pass the part without touching it.

The belt guide for the return pulley is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1975920

Update 21/12/2016

  • Work in progress status removed
  • Link to parts list added to description

Update 18/12/2016

  • Return pulley mount: Added a fillet to the hole for the nut. That should make printing without supports easier.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Nozzle 0.3mm / Layer 0,2mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Can be printed without supports

comments.text:
Good point. If you are concerned that the weight is too high you can rotate the part 180° when you mount it.
Then the driving pulley is 5mm closer to the bearing and the distance bearing<->pulley is about 15mm.
But - as far as I can see - it seems to work pretty well the way it is mounted on my printer.

description.text:
Remix of the repeating crossbow by Naus (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848665)

I've modified the initial design, mainly to make it printable without supports. I've also rounded the levers slightly, as well as increased the angle, to give room for proper cocking.

The pins have been thinned to enable snap assembly, though some glue is recommended.

To make it a lot more reliable, I recommend putting a short bit of shrink tubing on the middle of the rubber band, and heating it accordingly.

I've also added an optional finger-holder thingy, so that it's easier to operate- but this is strictly optional.

Printer:

Zortrax m200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

Maximum

Notes:

Print the arrow holder vertically, with the muzzle towards the print plate. You don't need supports!

Ensuring operational consistency

Take a piece of thick rubber band, maybe 7cm long. Thread it through a small piece of shrink tubing. Keep the rubber band stretched, and heat the tubing until it tightens around the rubber band. Let it cool before releasing the rubber band.

This will ensure proper release, and minimise the wear and tear on the rubber band.
Modifies with Cinema 4d. Some overhangs rounded out to enable support-less printing, as well as general structural improvements.

description.text: Inspired by nature's original winter decoration, we've created this Classical Icicle. Beautifully faceted to catch the light, this is the perfect hanging ornament for your home. description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54024

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=54024

Using the following options:

KnobHeight = 20
RingMarkings = 0
RingWidth = 5
ShaftLength = 0
Pointer2 = 1
Pointer1 = 1
HoleDiameter = 6.35
CapType = 0
HoleDepth = 10
Knurled = 1
KnobDiameter = 16
ShaftDiameter = 10
TimerKnob = 0
TaperPercentage = 20
ScrewHoleDiameter = 3
NotchedShaft = 0
HoleFlatThickness = 1

This is a harmonic drive. A harmonic drive is a very simple gear reducer that lends itself well to 3D printing.

It uses a rigid outer gear and an inner flex spline. The flex spline has a few less teeth (typically 2 less) than the outer gear. You stretch the flex spline so that it engages on opposite sides (typically) of the outer gear. The stretching mechanism, called the wave generator, rotates. This causes the flex spline to slowly advance along the outer gear in the opposite direction on the spinning wave generator. The ratio is...

Ratio = ( Flex - Outer ) / Flex

In my case that is...

(78 - 80) / 78 = -1/39

A good harmonic has zero backlash and is very strong. A large percent all of teeth are fully engaged at all times. It will also hold the position with the motor off. That is great on things like robot arms during loss of power. It also puts less load on servo motors.

I used Ninjatek Cheetah filament for the flex spline. It the slightly less flexible version of Ninjaflex. The flexing required is quite low. The ellipse formed on my unit is about 74mm x 70mm.

I was inspired by a few other designs but this was a clean sheet design. I wanted my own CAD model, where I could tweak. The settings. I designed the gears in Gearotic. They are just round spur gears with a 1 tooth per mm pitch and 20 deg pressure angle. A STEP model is included in the source files.

I plan to put this in a robot arm using stepper motor that need to be seriously geared down.

Design Tips

It appears to work better if the bottom of the flex spline is stiff. I bolted it to a rigid part to help with this.

You want a good bearing on the output. The flex spline will wobble outerwise

I tried to make the flex spline shorter, but it was not as smooth.

I am going to add more bearings to try to hold the material closer to the ideal ellipse. I think that will make it quieter and have less vibration (which is not bad...see the video)

Printing Tips

No support is need on any parts. My Z is typically wrong, so rotate the parts prior to printing.

The Cheetah sticks very well. Use blue tape and no heat. If you use a special surface like PEI, you might not get it off.

I tweaked my models for a perfect fit on the bearings and screws. You might need to do some tweaking on your own. The screws tap into the holes and the bearing press fits.

Video

Here is a video of it running

I think the input is running about 600rpm in the video and I have had it up to about 40% faster. Stepper don't like to go too fast, but they never stalled. I was using Grbl to run it and it max'ed out on speed.

Edit

I added a second version of the wave generator. This one uses an elliptical array of 10 5x16x5 bearings. The flex gear runs a lot smoother with this one. The un-meshed teeth tended to vibrate with the 2 bearing version.

comments.text: This is a really neat part!  I printed the flex spine in ABS and it had no problem with the necessary flex and it ran very smoothly with the 10 bearing inner assembly.  I didn't have the full assembly put together so the added rigidity may interfere with the overall fit and function but from a flex perspective it seemed good.  I suspect the ABS is less forgiving to tolerances between gears than the polyflex and I had to sand down the gears a bit to get a good fit though in part my printer isn't hugely accurate.

Fusion 360

A friend of mine asked me to build him a racing drone with the goal of using the Connex Prosight HD FPV system. For the frame, I chose the MQC One. My first reason for choosing the MQC One is because I like it. It's very functional, simple, and versatile. My second reason is that although it's only a 225mm frame, it's got a lot of space.

I used PETG to print the mounts. It should work with whatever you like using.

NOTE
I replaced the standard 30mm standoffs that come with the MQC One with 35mm standoffs.

Camera Mount
This slides over the front standoffs. The camera fits snugly.

Power Cable/RX Antenna Mount
This slides over the rear standoffs. You will have about half of the standoff showing after this part is on the drone. The VTX and VTX antenna mounts will use that space.

I use cable ties with shrink wrap to keep my RX antennas secure.

VTX / Antenna Mount
This is the most complicated group of parts to assemble. The Connex antenna plates need to be removed from the existing antenna, or order replacement plates. The plates fit tightly - it's a bit challenging to get them in the grooves, but once there, they will be snug. The VTX mount fits between the two antenna mount parts, which slide over the middle and rear standoffs (insert two of the 17mm spacers over the middle standoffs before inserting the VTX/antenna mounts parts). The VTX should be positioned so the antenna connectors face down. The reason for this is that there needs to be a flat clearance above the VTX for the battery straps. There is a lot of antenna wire to consider. I wound it up and zip tied them together between the camera and the VTX.

Printer:

Maker's Tool Works MiniMax

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used the wiggle infill pattern.
I printed with PETG at 230 degrees celcius with a 60 degree celcius bed, printing at 30mm/s.
Better Bridge

The individual "Crown Molding" files have an additional 64 vertices along the Z axis, allowing them to be effectively modified along a curve (in blender, at least). An example picture of this effect is shown above.

If the additional vertices aren't necessary for you, then simply download the "Crown Molding Pack", and that should be sufficient.

Units are in inches.

This is a bullet designed to hold one of my favorite magnets. The bullet is around 2/3" diameter and 2/3" tall.

The magnet is a 1/8 by 3/8 cylinder magnet from magnet4less.com. The magnet is inserted into the hole in the bottom, and fits well enough not to need glue.

It prints well without support.

Add a little gray paint for the lead and you've shot the fridge...oops...
